Description and usage of MsBackendSqlDb

Source: vignettes/MsBackendSqlDb.Rmd
MsBackendSqlDb.Rmd

Package: MsBackendSql
Authors: RforMassSpectrometry Package Maintainer [cre], Johannes Rainer [aut] (https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6977-7147), Chong Tang [aut], Laurent Gatto [aut] (https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1520-2268), Sebastian Gibb [aut] (https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7406-4443)
Last modified: 2021-06-24 12:14:19
Compiled: Thu Jun 24 12:15:51 2021

Introduction

This vignette will briefly introduce the usage of new SQLite-based backend MsBackendSqlDb. I will also compare MsBackendSqlDb to other backends to illustrate similarities and differences.

Usage

Firstly, we load the relevant packages:

library("Spectra")
library("RSQLite")
library("msdata")
library("MsBackendSql")
library("magrittr")

Creating Spectra objects with an MsBackendSqlDb backend

We will use a small sciex to create the backend objects.

fls <- dir(system.file("sciex", package = "msdata"), full.names = TRUE)
sp_mzr <- Spectra(fls, backend = MsBackendMzR())
sp_mzr
## MSn data (Spectra) with 1862 spectra in a MsBackendMzR backend:
##        msLevel     rtime scanIndex
##      <integer> <numeric> <integer>
## 1            1     0.280         1
## 2            1     0.559         2
## 3            1     0.838         3
## 4            1     1.117         4
## 5            1     1.396         5
## ...        ...       ...       ...
## 1858         1   258.636       927
## 1859         1   258.915       928
## 1860         1   259.194       929
## 1861         1   259.473       930
## 1862         1   259.752       931
##  ... 33 more variables/columns.
## 
## file(s):
## 20171016_POOL_POS_1_105-134.mzML
## 20171016_POOL_POS_3_105-134.mzML

For MsBackendSqlDb backend, we can choose either to create a connection object or to use the internal embedded connection object with a path in tempdir() to initialize a Spectra instance. In the following example, we will create a Spectra object with a new MsBackendSqlDb backend. Usually, SQLite allows at most one writer to proceed concurrently, hence we will use non-parallel execution to create the new Spectra object:

conn <- dbConnect(SQLite(), "msdata.db")
sp_sql <- Spectra(fls, backend = MsBackendSqlDb(), 
                  dbcon = conn,
                  BPPARAM = SerialParam())
## Warning: Closing open result set, pending rows

## Warning: Closing open result set, pending rows
sp_sql
## MSn data (Spectra) with 1862 spectra in a MsBackendSqlDb backend:
##     msLevel     rtime scanIndex
##   <integer> <numeric> <integer>
## 1         1     0.280         1
## 2         1     0.559         2
## 3         1     0.838         3
## ...     ...       ...       ...
## 1860      1   259.194       929
## 1861      1   259.473       930
## 1862      1   259.752       931
##  ... 33 more variables/columns.
## Processing:
##  Switch backend from MsBackendMzR to MsBackendSqlDb [Thu Jun 24 12:15:58 2021]

Can we load the mz and intensity values from the both backends?

mz1 <- mz(sp_mzr)
mz2 <- mz(sp_sql)
identical(mz1, mz2)
## [1] TRUE
intensity1 <- intensity(sp_mzr)
intensity2 <- intensity(sp_sql)
identical(intensity1, intensity2)
## [1] TRUE

Now we want to check the subsetting functions:

sp_mzr[6:20]

Below, we reproduce the example from the Spectra vignette, where spectra originating from the second file and acquired between 175 and 189 seconds are retained:

sp_mzr %>%
    filterDataOrigin(normalizePath(fls[2])) %>%
    filterRt(c(175, 189))
## MSn data (Spectra) with 50 spectra in a MsBackendMzR backend:
##       msLevel     rtime scanIndex
##     <integer> <numeric> <integer>
## 1           1   175.212       628
## 2           1   175.491       629
## 3           1   175.770       630
## 4           1   176.049       631
## 5           1   176.328       632
## ...       ...       ...       ...

##  Filter: select retention time [175..189] on MS level(s) 1 [Thu Jun 24 12:16:01 2021]
sp_sql %>%
    filterDataOrigin(normalizePath(fls[2])) %>%
    filterRt(c(175, 189))

##  Filter: select retention time [175..189] on MS level(s) 1 [Thu Jun 24 12:16:02 2021]

If we want to revert the filtering operations on the Spectra instance with a MsBackendSqlDb backend, we can also use reset function:

subset_sp <- sp_sql %>%
                 filterDataOrigin(normalizePath(fls[2])) %>%
                 filterRt(c(175, 189))
reset_sp <- reset(subset_sp)
reset_sp
## MSn data (Spectra) with 1862 spectra in a MsBackendSqlDb backend:
##     msLevel     rtime scanIndex
##   <integer> <numeric> <integer>
## 1         1     0.280         1
## 2         1     0.559         2
## 3         1     0.838         3
## ...     ...       ...       ...
## 1860      1   259.194       929
## 1861      1   259.473       930
## 1862      1   259.752       931
##  ... 33 more variables/columns.
## Processing:
##  Switch backend from MsBackendMzR to MsBackendSqlDb [Thu Jun 24 12:15:58 2021]
##  Filter: select data origin(s) /Users/runner/work/_temp/Library/msdata/sciex/20171016_POOL_POS_3_105-134.mzML [Thu Jun 24 12:16:02 2021]
##  Filter: select retention time [175..189] on MS level(s) 1 [Thu Jun 24 12:16:02 2021]
##  ...1 more processings. Use 'processingLog' to list all.

If we now compare the memory footprint of the Spectra objects with the respective backends. sp_mzr uses the MsBackendMzR backend that stored the metadata in memory, and accessed the raw data (m/z and intensities) on demand directly in the mzML files.

print(object.size(sp_mzr), units = "Kb")
## 386.2 Kb

sp_sql uses the MsBackendSqlDb backend that stored neither in memory. The metadata and the raw data are stored in a SQLite file (msdata.db defined above), and thus further minimses the memory footprint.

print(object.size(sp_sql), units = "Kb")
## 18.9 Kb

Both these backends are implemented to minimise memory usage, as opposed to a full in-memory backend that stores all data and metadata in RAM:

sp_df <- setBackend(sp_sql, MsBackendDataFrame())
print(object.size(sp_df), units = "Mb")
## 52.4 Mb

We can also create a merged Spectra object by using several small MsBackendSqlDb backends. Firstly, we can create 2 distinct Spectra instances with MsBackendMzR backends:

sp_mzr1 <- sp_mzr %>% filterDataOrigin(normalizePath(fls[1]))
sp_mzr2 <- sp_mzr %>% filterDataOrigin(normalizePath(fls[2]))

We switch the backends to MsBackendSqlDb:

sp_sql1 <- setBackend(sp_mzr1, MsBackendSqlDb())
## Warning: Closing open result set, pending rows

## Warning: Closing open result set, pending rows
sp_sql2 <- setBackend(sp_mzr2, MsBackendSqlDb())
## Warning: Closing open result set, pending rows

## Warning: Closing open result set, pending rows

Now we want to merge these 2 smaller Spectra objects into one Spectra object with MsBackendSqlDb backend:

mergedBackendSql <- backendMerge(sp_sql1@backend, sp_sql2@backend)
sp_sql_merged <- Spectra(backend = mergedBackendSql)
sp_sql_merged
## MSn data (Spectra) with 1862 spectra in a MsBackendSqlDb backend:
##     msLevel     rtime scanIndex
##   <integer> <numeric> <integer>
## 1         1     0.280         1
## 2         1     0.559         2
## 3         1     0.838         3
## ...     ...       ...       ...
## 1860      1   259.194       929
## 1861      1   259.473       930
## 1862      1   259.752       931
##  ... 33 more variables/columns.

The merged Spectra object has its SQLite database file in the tempdir() directory.

identical(sp_sql_merged$mz, sp_sql$mz)
## [1] TRUE
identical(sp_sql_merged$intensity, sp_sql$intensity)
## [1] TRUE
identical(sp_sql_merged$dataOrigin, sp_sql$dataOrigin)
## [1] TRUE

The MsBackendSqlDb also provides writing functionality to users:

sp_sql_merged$dataOrigin <- rep("DDUV", length(sp_sql_merged))
## Warning: Closing open result set, pending rows
print(unique(sp_sql_merged$dataOrigin))
## [1] "DDUV"
